Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Enhanced Circular Dichroism Sensing of Biomolecules Using Nanoparticles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal: 1403947/1403226
PI: Balaz, Milan/Dzyuba, Sergei
Collaborative Research: Enhanced Circular Dichroism Sensing of Biomolecules Using Nanoparticles

Technical terms: The proposed project aims to utilize achiral metallic or semiconductor nanoparticles (NPs) to enhance and modulate circular dichroism (CD) signal of chiral biomolecules. CD is the preferred technique for detection and analysis of chiral compounds and their interactions. Significant enhancement of the sensitivity of CD spectroscopy coupled with the ability to shift CD signals to longer wavelengths will allow examining structures of biological molecules as well as supramolecular biorecognition phenomena at biologically relevant concentrations with minimal amount of unwanted overlaps. The enhanced sensitivity and modularity is anticipated to rise from the electronic coupling between achiral NPs and chiral molecules in their proximity. We will prepare achiral NPs functionalized with chiral molecules and study their structure and experimental CD characteristics. We will perform theoretical simulations of CD spectra to gain detailed structural and mechanistic insights into the origins of induced CD in metallic and semiconductor NPs capped with chiral biomolecules. This is the first time that the achiral metallic and semiconductor NPs will be designed and optimized to specifically enhance CD of chiral molecules. The project will further enhance our understanding of the origin of induced chiroptical activity in achiral metallic and semiconductor NPs and will have an immediate impact on the fields of biosensing and chiroptical nanomaterials.

Layman terms: Circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy allows to detect chiral biomolecules and study their interactions. The project will develop novel methods that enhance the sensitivity and resolution of CD detection by utilizing metallic or semiconductor particles of nanometer size as potent amplifiers of CD signal. Enhanced signal detection will be strongly beneficial for the detection and study of low concentration and complex mixture of biologically active molecules that are difficult to explore by current methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objectives of the grant were to gain a better understanding of the origin of optical activity (also referred to as chirality) in metallic nanoparticles and their small organic molecule conjugates (also referred to as capping ligands) as well as to explore experimental approaches towards increasing the sensitivity of spectroscopic techniques that could detect optically active compounds. It was envisioned that by achieving an effective functionalization of the nanoparticles with various optically active small molecules will allow to explore fascinating challenges from the synthetic, computational and spectroscopic points of view.

            The outcome of the research activities provided several significant results that appear to challenge modern paradigms on how to induce optical activity onto nanoparticle types of scaffolds. Specifically, it is widely accepted that the chirality of the capping ligand is responsible for the induced chirality of the nanoparticles. However, this research demonstrated that chirality inversion in nanoparticles is possible without changing the chirality of the capping ligands. In turn, using computational tools, it was established that the specific binding interactions between capping ligands control the overall chirality of the nanoparticle-ligand conjugates. In addition, the structural requirements for the capping ligands have been developed, and general guidelines for designing capping ligands that would be capable of inducing optical activity into the nanoparticles were formulated. This discovery provides a novel approach to the rational design of structurally and functionally diverse, optically active nanoparticles, and it expected to have a significant impact on the field of optically active nanomaterials, which have ever-expanding applications in sensing, especially as environmentally sensitive probes.

            Furthermore, this research provided an opportunity to explore other directions, which primary focused on developing environmentally sensitive probes based on small organic molecules. As a result, a combination of these research activities, i.e., optically active nanoparticles and environmental probes, constitutes the main thrust of the research and educational activities in the group.

            In addition, a number of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students (a total of 15 over the 3 year grant period) have been exposed to various aspects of the research and received a hands-on-training in a variety of disciplines. The outcomes of the research has lead to eight publications (with several being in various stages of preparation for publication), several presentations, which were given by the members of the group at local and national meetings. Also, this research allowed to establish several interdisciplinary collaborations.

Overall this project provided an exciting synergism of synthetic, nanotechnological, spectroscopic and educational activities.
